reviewText:
There should be more people playing this game online. It looks amazing, it plays really smoothly, it has a very fast paced gameplay.
The player movement feels a bit strange at first, but you get used to it pretty fast.

About the weapons: They are very varied and have very specific roles and situations to be used on effectively.
You only get to choose 2 weapons at a time. That means you can't adapt to situations without dying, choosing a different loadout and respawning. Level design doesn't give you that many situations either. The levels are very open arenas, made to showcase the awesome gravity gameplay. It's a bit strange to just walk and use the planet you're standing on as cover. But there's enough weapon variety for people with higher pings to have a lot of fun, without having to rely solely on accuracy to get some kills.

There's 2 main gametypes. The classic DeathMatch, and Orbital Warfare. The later one being the most strategic, requiring you to defend your structures while attacking the enemy base. While there is potential for tactics here, the matches tend to be very offensive. There's no tools to provide support roles (you need to kill enemies to repair structures), or to play defensively (the shield item lasts a couple of seconds and doesn't stop enemies). So you'll really need to coordinate with your teammates to create a good minefield defense, or a satellite based defense line. Otherwise, it ends up feeling like team deathmatch with some extra objectives.
Placeable roadblocks, a big permanent shield item that can cover an entire structure for 30 seconds but with a 15 seconds cooldown, big mines that follow the orbit of the planet it was deployed on, or an item that teleports you back to your base, could be features that might spice up that gamemode.

This is a very well crafted game. I really hope future updates bring some more maps to play on, and some sort of single player contents, for those days when we can't find online games.

reviewText: Simplicity is both a virtue and a vice in Orbital Gears, a 2.5D side-scrolling multiplayer-only shooter armed with an interesting gimmick: the gravitational fields of deep space.The virtue is that, as a giant mech, you run around planets -- quite literally, in this case -- using their gravity to zip around a solar system-sized map, hopping Orbital Gear from one world to the next and shooting opponents. The vice is that, well, that’s about all there is to it. A paltry two modes, Deathmatch and Orbital Warfare, are included. Deathmatch is self-explanatory; Orbital Warfare is a more strategic team-based affair that’s essentially King of the Hill in space.There aren’t too many surprises in level layouts, either. The six Deathmatch maps and three Orbital Warfare maps are pretty similar to one another.While there are numerous weapons to choose from, and finding ways of making them interact with the environment is enjoyable, the majority of them suffer a common flaw. They have this weird half-second delay in their initial firing - with the exception of the mini-gun, which has to spool up.The total lack of single-player content though, actually negatively impacts the multiplayer side of the equation to a fair degree.Mainly because, even a week and a half after launch, there are at most a small handful of servers available at any one time, and often none whatsoever. Without other people playing, a multiplayer online-only shooter is about as useful as a disconnected telephone.Orbital Gear can be a frantic shooter that pulls you in with its gravitational gimmickry, but lacks the forward momentum to keep me playing for long.Overall 6/10.

UPDATEThe promised single-player feature has been released - it's called Orbital Trials where you have to kill certain baddies with certain weapons as fast as you can. The faster you go, the more stars you get. You need to collect a certain amount of stars to unlock the next one.
It's an interesting single-player mode, but I'd much have preferred normal Deathmatch/Orbital Warfare battles with bots instead. Still, at least there's something to do in single-player. I've increased my rating below.
Original unedited review follows.
----------------------------------------------
This game got onto Steam as a result of Who's Gaming Now?!'s free key for a Greenlight vote promotion. In truth, after playing this game for a while, I felt that it wasn't really needed - this game was fantastic, entertaining and it blew me away, and it could probably have gotten onto Steam by merit alone. (Though I would no doubt agree that WGN?! gave it the much-needed exposure it deserved.)

Orbital Gear is a 2D space game with beautiful 3D graphics about fighting mechs (called 'Gears'). There are 12 interesting weapons with defining characteristics, 2 game modes (plain deathmatch and Orbital Warfare where teams destroy opposing team buildings) and 4 other mech utilities. A great variety of maps coupled with the weapon choices make for some interesting battles as you mix and match your gear (pun unintended) to get an optimal setup.

What Orbital Gear has going for it is its rather fresh combination of 2D platform shooting and planet gravity mechanics. Flying (gliding, rather) around the planets, jumping around from here to there is a rather exhilarating and heart-racing experience. The gravity mechanics really shake up the game a lot, and are a very solid foundation to build upon. (I mean, because of all the gravity, you're firmly planted to the foundation.....never mind.)

Where the game (currently) falls short in is the fact that it's for now a multiplayer-only game. Now it's no secret that on Steam most multiplayer-only games are rendered lifeless within months, because everyone will be going back to their DOTAs, their CSGOs, their TF2s, and so on and so forth. As such, during the time I spent playing, I only found a maximum of 2 open games at any point of time, some with only 1 player. Developer Night Node has promised to add a practice single player mode in future updates, but for now I'd recommend being wary of this.

Despite the major lack of single player shortcomings, the rest of the game already feels quite polished and well done. I'd recommend checking this game out with a few friends if you have the time. Oh, and the electronic soundtrack is surprisingly great, too.

When to buy: With the lack of people in multiplayer, unfortunately I feel it best to buy it from bundles. The single player mode is like a snack - not very filling.

8.5/10

reviewText:
Since you are probably skimming through the reviews to make up your mind on a purchase, I’ll save you some time and summarise this game with three words, they are cheap (price tag), stylish (graphics) and fun (game play). If that wasn’t enough to convince you, read on.

This title is essentially an arena game set upon a 2D platform with 3D graphics, the twist revolves around the clever implementation of gravity around structures and planets, with which the players will use to maneuver their mechs. The system can be confusing at first, but very rewarding once a player gets the hang of it, I was pulling gravitational slingshot and performing swing-by shooting within an hour.

The guns themselves are fairly mundane and standard among this type of game, but the twelve of them do vary a great deal in terms of play style and tactics. There are four utility tools available as well, but I rarely see people use them to much effect in game.

As for game modes, you have the basic Death Match which is self explanatory. Then you have Orbital Warfare, a territorial tug-of-war in which both teams race to charge up their main cannons for a devastating blast. Lastly you have Orbital Trials, a single player time attack mode that pits you up against patrolling machines on a map with limited weaponry; this was added by the developers after much request from the community.

The only problem I had with the game was the lack of bots, so if you just wanted a private match with a friend or two, the arena would feel very desolate. Other than that I felt the community could do better with a few thousand more players, so it would be easier to find games during different hours of the day.

The asking price of 10 USD is fine, but if you find this under 1 USD during a sale, it would be a practical steal.

reviewText:
Orbital Gear is a fun fast paced shooter with some really fun design choices.

Pros:
[+] Guns are satisfying. There are 12 in all, and each one is very unique. Using a different gun feels like using a different class in Tf2, and each one has a satisfying hit. There are a lot of high impact weapons, so dieing is quick, but so are respawn timers so there's very little to no downtime.

[+] Movement is great. It takes a little bit to get used to the gravity mechanic, but once you understand how to manipulate it in your favor, sling shotting yourself across the map feels really great. There are single player time trials to help you learn them.

[+] High skill high reward. The nice thing about the game is that it's consistent. There's a lot of room to learn the movement system, a lot of room to learn how to position yourself relative to certain guns, aiming with projectiles has a ton of depth, and overall just being good at aiming + Reaction is very rewarding. Some combinations will seem overpowered, but then you realize that there are counters to most everything and most things are pretty balanced. For example, when I first got the game it seemed to me the gauntlet was the most broken weapon in the game, but after a couple hours you realize that it gets absolutely destroyed by any of the shotgun-esque weapons and overall just positioning.

Cons:
[-] Very little lag compensation. Servers are player hosted, and even when playing with people who have relatively low ping, (like 20-50) you'll have people teleporting their locations. Super frustrating and honestly the biggest negative.

[-] Lack of feedback. There's  no indication of whether or not you hit somebody else. You can shoot at someone multiple times and have no idea if you've actually damaged them. Not usually an issue since most weapons tend to be very high damaging, and most of the time 1-4 shots will kill someone (lending to the fast paced nature of the game, but would be a nice, easy fix.

[-] Small Player base. I've checked other server regions a couple times, and asian /australian regions have no servers usually. American and European servers tend to have a couple servers running so if you live in either of those places it should be fine.

Verdict: As of writing this the game is on sale for a dollar, and at that price the game is absolutely worth getting. I see it's also been in packs and bundles before for a couple dollars and that'd also be worth it. I personally wouldn't recommend the game for 10 dollars, but just a little bit off of that and its an amazing deal.

reviewText:
This game is great. At first, you have no clue what to do because the game is unclear about it, so you start with missions and you muddle through that because of the trailer you saw of the game was cool and it had good reviews. Then you look around and decided to try the online multiplayer and you have no clue what the heck is going on because everything is exploding you don't really understand the different weapons or the mechanics but you're having a ton of fun because THAT is what you saw in the trailer. (And then you go back to the missions and realize that they're actually practice for all the different weapon types)

What is the game? You're a mech running around a bunch of planets in 2D, each with their own gravity, trying to shoot other mechs. There's a variety of options for guns, powerups and mechs. You can choose between two game modes or try the singleplayer missions for practice.

Good Stuff:
-Awesome gameplay
-Great concept
-Simple Controls
-Actually and simply just fun to play

What needs improvement:
-Server lag, other people have mentioned this, and they're right, sometimes it's hard to play because of lag
-Starting off you don't really understand how weapons work or what you're doing, and the game only partially explains what you're doing


If you give this game an hour, you'll understand the controls and what you're doing and you'll really love it, because it really is a great game.

reviewText:
2D, Fast paced, Mech shooter.
Orbital gear in a nutshell.

The gameplay is fun, you run and jump around a small level trying to kill the other guys. Sounds simpel, and yes, sometimes it is just that simpel. But the planets you jump on have gravity that effects everyone, meanning you have to take into account that if you jump you might not move up, or if you miss a planet you may end up slingshotting yourself halfway across the map. The offline time trials provide a fairly good introduction to the base mechanics but i found that trial by fire in multiplayer did more for me. Because it is really in the multiplayer aspects this game shines. The weapon and map variety is also nice. So far all the levels seems fun and with great opportunities for frantic combat. The guns also seem different and handle different with i quite like. That means that every gun will require a unique playstyle and offer different challenges.

To sum up
Gameplay: 8/10. The gameplay is excellent if you are looking for a fun and frantic little 2D shooter.

Weapons: 7/10. The weapons are nicely varied and well balanced, i do however have some personal issues with the some weapons. Namely the Phase orb.

Sound: 6/10. The guns sound good, the music sounds good and the annoucer is not annoying. All in all, very good.

Levels: 7/10. All the levels are small enough to put you close to the action while still allowing for breathing room.

Looks: 8/10. Everything looks excellent. The background in the leves looks nice and fits with every level, pretty enough to catch your eye, inconspicuous enough to not be distracting. The weapons looks nice when fired and so does the projectiles

All in all: 8/10. Execellent game

reviewText:
Orbital Gear is one of the most legitimately fun games I have ever played. It is fun for the sake of being fun. I'm not even that good, and yet, I still am laughing and having a blast whenever I decide to play it. It's fast, frantic, and wonderfully competitive, while being as simplistic as possible at the same time. I highly recommend this game. Get some friends together, start a Skype chat, and play. And now, until June 1, it's available for just a $1!
Pros
- Even when running at maxed out settings, it runs ridiculously smooth. Plus it looks gorgeous and has a perfect, distinct style.
- The controls, while at first are frustrating, quickly become very familiar.
- The use of gravity as a main gameplay element was actually pretty well implemented. Not perfect by any means, but it works for a majority of stages in the game.
- The variety of weapons and stages is great. Each stage and weapon feels distinct. Having a favorite pairing of weapons, and a utility (a sort of enhancement for the user's mech) and then proceeding to master that loadout, feels just like having a favorite Smash Bros. character.
Cons
- Having controller support as an option may in itself sound great, but using a controller for this game sucks. It just doesn't work.
- There are a number of different mechs to choose from from within the game. They all look different, with a great retro 80s 90s vibe, but the mechs themselves are just cosmetic, and don't really change anything. Plus within the game, they appear super tiny, so that was pretty useless.
- Lack of replayability. Everything is already unlocked in this game the second you turn it on. Weapons, mechs, stages, everything.
Anyways though, these cons are very minor as a whole really, and don't in anyway hinder the amount of childlike fun with this game. 9/10

reviewText:
I like this game, I really do.

It has fun, silly weapons/support items that are situationally OP (depending on map) meaning you need to learn them all and understand when to switch to counter your opponents.

Movement is a blast, getting flung around planets at increasingly high speeds and then landing on top of someone with a pulse rocket explosion is great.

Visuals are simple but crisp, everything is low-poly but some excellent colour choice and parallax effects really sell it. Each stage is unique in both appearance and layout, every single one is worth experiencing. The mechs themselves look okay at best (very N64-steez), but that barely matters since you view them from such a zoomed out perspective.

The sound effects are stellar, and the music is a fun, pumping, Tron-style track that matches the on-screen action to a T.

It just has one huge problem: No one is playing it. The only time there is ever a server is when me and my friends go make one to play with 4 players.

So fair warning; bring friends who you can hit up to play with you. You will almost never find active servers with more than 1 or 2 people in them, and even then the lag can be just agony.

tl;dr (summary)This is a great game, you should definitly buy it. Interesting take on a platform shooter. I absolutly love the gravity, graphics and other parts of gameplay. It really helps to know people who have the game so that you can get a full multiplayer game going. Overall 9/10.

About the gameOrbital gear is a paralax 3d platformer, with planets that each have their own gravitational pull. Bullets curve with the gravity, utilities create fast paced gameplay and bullets storm and explode. Mostly an online multiplayer game with simple but effective making. There are single player time trial modes which aren't good enough for long term gameplay, but good enough for practive. There is a local multiplayer also.

My thoughtsThis is a great game, the community is small but incredibly nice and helpful. I was glad to see that despite the small community I was able to get into a match within 5 seconds of joining online. The game goes on sale for cheap which is great. I bought the 4 pack for some of my freinds and family, so far my only regret is that I didn't buy two 4 packs. There are some good and bad things about the game, maybe the devs will update it some more.

reviewText:
UNDER RATED. Let it grow on you. The movement in my opinion takes time getting use to. I was navigating sloppily for a while, but it all pays off with practice. Nothing like it. Though the server browser isn't all that active, the single player challenges are addicting. They're tough but satisfying when you complete them. But good luck making a mark on the worldwide leaderboards. I came no where near the times listed. Those records are mindblowing so I play this purely for the fun, stopping to smell the roses. I only care about completing these and enjoying myself. That's more than enough. I could care less if the time aspect was here.

The music brings you deep into the game immediately. It's top notch.

I also like how it's as fast paced as arena shooters like quake and unreal tournament, if not faster.

Abilities like boost, shield, mines seem to be each as useful as one another if you utilize them well and adds that last layer of gameplay that's needed.

This is a very unique and original game but manages to be simple and straight forward at the same time. What I mean by that is that there are few gameplay aspects that collectively make up this game that wouldn't benefit from anything additional to that.  Why tamper too much with a great steak. You're not going to put ketchup on that are you?

tl;dr (summary)This is a great game, you should definitly buy it. Interesting take on a platform shooter. I absolutly love the gravity, graphics and other parts of gameplay. It really helps to know people who have the game so that you can get a full multiplayer game going. Overall 9/10.

About the gameOrbital gear is a paralax 3d platformer, with planets that each have their own gravitational pull. Bullets curve with the gravity, utilities create fast paced gameplay and bullets storm and explode. Mostly an online multiplayer game with simple but effective making. There are single player time trial modes which aren't good enough for long term gameplay, but good enough for practive. There is a local multiplayer also.

My thoughtsThis is a great game, the community is small but incredibly nice and helpful. I was glad to see that despite the small community I was able to get into a match within 5 seconds of joining online. The game goes on sale for cheap which is great. I bought the 4 pack for some of my freinds and family, so far my only regret is that I didn't buy two 4 packs. There are some good and bad things about the game, maybe the devs will update it some more.

What it needsA health bar over each player would be great, knowing if a weapon is strong enough to kill someone is a must. It also needs bots, some of the maps are so large that two players can run around without seeing each other.

The goods and the badsGood
Easy to learn to play
Helpful Community
Fun

The way that gravity affects players and bullets
Interesting Concept

Reasonably good gun balance
Graphics are awesome
Bad

Controls vary from map to map (ie. you dont need up/down on some maps while on others they are necessary)

No bots
